Award.AwardTitle: 2018 Frontiers of Engineering Symposia (US FOE and Japan-America FOE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide emerging engineering leaders from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share research insights to facilitate an interdisciplinary transfer of knowledge and research methodologies. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic growth in an increasingly competitive environment have heightened the need for engineers to understand each other's disciplines and enhance the value in that interaction, particularly among those developing and using these new technologies. The symposia serve as a catalyst to spur engineering innovation and foster collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and between engineers from the United States and partnering countries.

This award will provide partial support for two Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) symposia, to be held in 2018, organized by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) for early career researchers: the Japan-America FOE to be held in Tsukuba, Japan on June 18-20, 2018 and the US FOE to be hosted by MIT Lincoln Lab in Lexington, Massachusetts on September 5-7, 2018. The 2018 US FOE symposium will focus on Quantum Computing, Resilient and Reliable Infrastructure, Theranostics: Diagnostics+Therapy, and Technology for Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief. The 2018 JAFOE symposium will focus on Advanced AI, The Water Treatment Revolution, Bionics and Prosthetics, Smart Structures and Materials. Approximately 100 outstanding young engineers for the U.S. symposium and 30 from each country for the bilateral symposia will participate. Each two and one-half day symposium will include plenary sessions, technical tours, break-out sessions, and opportunities for developing collaborative research partnerships. Sessions will consist of presentations on cutting-edge research, innovations, and emerging research opportunities in engineering fields relevant to the symposium. FOE symposium papers, abstracts, presentation videos, and slides will be made available on the FOE website (www.naefrontiers.org ).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide highly accomplished early-career engineers from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share research insights to facilitate an interdisciplinary transfer of knowledge and research methodologies. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic growth in an increasingly competitive environment have heightened the need for engineers to understand each other's disciplines. The symposia are a catalyst for engineering innovation that fosters collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and across national boundaries. This award provided partial support for the Japan-America FOE (June 18-20 in Tsukuba, Japan) and the US FOE (September 5-7, in Lexington, Mass.). Each FOE symposium focused on four session topics: for US FOE, quantum computers, the role of engineering in the face of conflict and disaster, resilient and reliable infrastructure, and theranostics, and for JAFOE, water treatment, bionics and prosthetics, smart structures and materials, and artificial intelligence. The symposia comprised plenary sessions focused on cutting-edge research and technical work; cultural and/or technical tours,and  break-out sessions. Symposium papers, abstracts, and presentation slides were made available on the FOE website (www.naefrontiers.org).

Outcomes from evaluation forms:

JAPAN-AMERICA FRONTIERS OF ENGINEERING

Rated good or excellent:
Meeting format  97%
Choice of topics  91%
Quality of presentations  100%
Level of engineering covered  94%
Opportunity to participate  97%

Comments:

"I was unsure what to expect before arriving but I very much appreciated the format. My own research area was a bit outside the four chosen topics, but it was a great opportunity to expose myself to ideas and areas in which I am not an expert. The participants were wonderful too -- knowledgeable and friendly."

"A team from Horiba has already visited my institution after the meeting."

"It was an eye-opening, inspiring experience with respect to engineering as a whole and good to get outside the box by attending a conference not specific to my field."

"Listening to experts in the selected fields was very effective to learn about research fields outside of my own expertise. Also, I found the philosophical and cultural differences in approaches to research between the US and Japan very interesting."

"The symposium is useful because people with diverse expertise can mix. Plus the symposium is highly prestigious."

US FRONTIERS OF ENGINEERING

Rated good or excellent:
Meeting format  93%
Choice of topics  93%
Quality of presentations  96%
Level of engineering covered  87%
Opportunity to participate  96%

Comments:

"Presentation quality was excellent. For concepts that are outside the normal area of expertise for most engineers (e.g., quantum computing), the presenters did a great job explaining complex concepts in understandable language."

"This was one of the most wonderful opportunities I have experienced academically. The chance to interact with other young-and mid-career scientists from different disciplines was unique. The topics chosen for the speakers were interesting to everyone because they covered areas of national interest. The format of the sessions was also terrific. I appreciated the general introduction followed by specific topics. This was an enlightening experience, scientifically and personally."

"One future outcome is I can use machine learning to evaluate different materials that can be used in my research area."

"I plan to start a collaboration in the field of machine learning to help me find the best candidate to be used as a solid electrolyte in energy storage applications."

"I don't often have the opportunity to interact with people in industry so it was extremely helpful to learn about their work and applications."

"Having long breaks and social events helped to facilitate in-depth conversations about research. It is rare that I get to have time at a meeting to really get into the heart of the engineering that is conducted in my lab. Also, I have never been to an engineering meeting that was half women. Participating in this meeting was a truly transformative experience for me because it was so diverse. I found myself at a comfort level that I have never experienced before because there were more people there with similar experiences as mine. I found myself being more open about my work and my approach. I truly appreciate these interactions."

"It was extremeely useful to learn how engineers in disciplines rather disparate from my own think and approach problems. I was astounded by that diversity and am already taking this (for me) out-of-the-box thinking and trying to apply it to my work."

GRAINGER GRANTS

Two grants of $30,000. from The Grainger Foundation were awarded to 2018 attendees who developed collaborative research projects. The recipients were:

Lee Bassett and Andrew Tsourkas (University of Pennsylvania) for their proposal, "Engineering Quantum-Biological Interfaces for Nontoxic Theranostic Agents."

Andrew Detor (GE Global Research) and Corey Trobaugh (Cummins) for their proposal, "Cummins-GE Collaboration on Aluminum Alloy Development."
